section.title: Introduction
section.paragraph: Godot has a serialization API based on Variant. It's used for converting data types to an array of bytes efficiently. This API is exposed via the global bytes_to_var() and var_to_bytes() functions, but it is also used in the get_var and store_var methods of FileAccess as well as the packet APIs for PacketPeer. This format is not used for binary scenes and resources.

section.names: full\ objects\ vs\ object\ instance\ ids
section.title: Full Objects vs Object instance IDs
section.paragraph: If a variable is serialized with full_objects = true, then any Objects contained in the variable will be serialized and included in the result. This is recursive.
If full_objects = false, then only the instance IDs will be serialized for any Objects contained in the variable.

section.title: Packet specification
section.paragraph: The packet is designed to be always padded to 4 bytes. All values are little-endian-encoded. All packets have a 4-byte header representing an integer, specifying the type of data.
The lowest value two bytes are used to determine the type, while the highest value two bytes contain flags:

Following this is the actual packet contents, which varies for each type of packet. Note that this assumes Godot is compiled with single-precision floats, which is the default. If Godot was compiled with double-precision floats, the length of "Float" fields within data structures should be 8, and the offset should be (offset - 4) * 2 + 4. The "float" type itself always uses double precision.

section.title: 2: int
section.paragraph: If no flags are set (flags == 0), the integer is sent as a 32 bit integer:
If flag ENCODE_FLAG_64 is set (flags & 1 == 1), the integer is sent as a 64-bit integer:

section.title: 3: float
section.paragraph: If no flags are set (flags == 0), the float is sent as a 32 bit single precision:
If flag ENCODE_FLAG_64 is set (flags & 1 == 1), the float is sent as a 64-bit double precision number:

section.title: 4: String
section.paragraph: This field is padded to 4 bytes.

entry.paragraph: The X component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][0]
The Y component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][1]
The X component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][0]
The Y component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][1]
The X component of the origin vector, accessed via [2][0]
The Y component of the origin vector, accessed via [2][1]
The X component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][0]
The Y component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][1]
The Z component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][2]
The X component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][0]
The Y component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][1]
The Z component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][2]
The X component of the Z column vector, accessed via [2][0]
The Y component of the Z column vector, accessed via [2][1]
The Z component of the Z column vector, accessed via [2][2]
The X component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][0]
The Y component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][1]
The Z component of the X column vector, accessed via [0][2]
The X component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][0]
The Y component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][1]
The Z component of the Y column vector, accessed via [1][2]
The X component of the Z column vector, accessed via [2][0]
The Y component of the Z column vector, accessed via [2][1]
The Z component of the Z column vector, accessed via [2][2]
The X component of the origin vector, accessed via [3][0]
The Y component of the origin vector, accessed via [3][1]
The Z component of the origin vector, accessed via [3][2]
Red (typically 0..1, can be above 1 for overbright colors)
Green (typically 0..1, can be above 1 for overbright colors)
Blue (typically 0..1, can be above 1 for overbright colors)
String length, or new format (val&0x80000000!=0 and NameCount=val&0x7FFFFFFF)

section.title: For old format:
section.paragraph: Padded to 4 bytes.

section.title: For new format:
section.paragraph: For each Name and Sub-Name
Every name string is padded to 4 bytes.

section.title: 17: Object
section.paragraph: An Object could be serialized in three different ways: as a null value, with full_objects = false, or with full_objects = true.

entry.paragraph: The Object instance ID (64-bit signed integer)

section.title: full_objects enabled

entry.paragraph: The number of properties that are serialized

section.paragraph: For each property:

entry.paragraph: Property value, using this same format

note.paragraph: Not all properties are included. Only properties that are configured with the PROPERTY_USAGE_STORAGE flag set will be serialized. You can add a new usage flag to a property by overriding the _get_property_list method in your class. You can also check how property usage is configured by calling Object._get_property_list See PropertyUsageFlags for the possible usage flags.

section.title: 18: Dictionary
section.paragraph: Then what follows is, for amount of "elements", pairs of key and value, one after the other, using this same format.

section.title: 19: Array
section.paragraph: Then what follows is, for amount of "elements", values one after the other, using this same format.

section.title: 20: PackedByteArray
section.paragraph: The array data is padded to 4 bytes.

section.title: 25: PackedStringArray
section.paragraph: For each String:
Every string is padded to 4 bytes.

entry.paragraph: Red (typically 0..1, can be above 1 for overbright colors)
Green (typically 0..1, can be above 1 for overbright colors)
Blue (typically 0..1, can be above 1 for overbright colors)
